body:
[Here](https://github.com/OneGet/oneget/blob/08ae6e82df2230a601ed09191b26712b213afbc5/src/Microsoft.PackageManagement/Utility/Extensions/FilesystemExtensions.cs#L252)'s where your stack trace points to.

However, given the type of exception, I'm guessing the actual issue lies with [this method](https://github.com/OneGet/oneget/blob/08ae6e82df2230a601ed09191b26712b213afbc5/src/Microsoft.PackageManagement/Utility/Extensions/FilesystemExtensions.cs#L121).

We'd probably get a better stack trace if we could call that method directly. All we need to do is use some reflection to get the type. I can provide code in a bit.

```powershell
# Ensure the PackageManagement module is loaded so we have the assembly loaded
Import-Module PackageManagement

# Get the needed internal type
$type = [Microsoft.PackageManagement.Internal.Utility.Versions.FourPartVersion].Assembly.GetType('Microsoft.PackageManagement.Internal.Utility.Extensions.FilesystemExtensions')

# Now call the method
$type::ResetTempFolder()

# If there's an error, use this to display it fully
Get-Error
```

> ```powershell
> # Ensure the PackageManagement module is loaded so we have the assembly loaded
> Import-Module PackageManagement
> 
> # Get the needed internal type
> $type = [Microsoft.PackageManagement.Internal.Utility.Versions.FourPartVersion].Assembly.GetType('Microsoft.PackageManagement.Internal.Utility.Extensions.FilesystemExtensions')
> 
> # Now call the method
> $type::ResetTempFolder()
> 
> # If there's an error, use this to display it fully
> Get-Error
> ```

Thanks Rob

### PSHome
/opt/microsoft/powershell/7

```
MethodInvocationException: Exception calling "ResetTempFolder" with "0" argument(s): "The type initializer for 'Microsoft.PackageManagement.Internal.Utility.Extensions.FilesystemExt
ensions' threw an exception."
```

> ```
>  Message        : Access to the path '/tmp/Microsoft.PackageManagement' is denied.
>  InnerException :
>     Type    : System.IO.IOException
>      Message : Permission denied
>      HResult : 13
>  Source         : System.IO.FileSystem
>  HResult        : -2147024891
> ```

Ah looks like it might be a permissions issue on `/tmp/Microsoft.PackageManagement`

Just for fuller context in case anyone hits issues here:

- Modules were initially installed as root by an agent on the system
- Later, commands were run by a non-root user and the permissions on `/tmp/Microsoft.PackageManagement` didn't allow for reading
- This was solved with `chmod o+r /tmp/Microsoft.PackageManagement` (or a similar addition of permissions on the directory for other users)
- An issue remains with modules installed to the `AllUsers` directory only being available to `root`

> Just for fuller context in case anyone hits issues here:
> 
> * Modules were initially installed as root by an agent on the system
> * Later, commands were run by a non-root user and the permissions on `/tmp/Microsoft.PackageManagement` didn't allow for reading
> * This was solved with `chmod o+r /tmp/Microsoft.PackageManagement` (or a similar addition of permissions on the directory for other users)
> * An issue remains with modules installed to the `AllUsers` directory only being available to `root`

Thanks Rob:

- `umask` = `0027` (For both Ubuntu 18.04 and Ubuntu 20.04)
- Permissions on `/tmp/Microsoft.PackageManagement` is `1750` (For Ubuntu 20.04) and `1755` (For Ubuntu 18.04) sharing same umask.
- Permsisions on `/usr/local/share/powershell/` is `0750` (For Ubuntu 20.04) and `0755` (For Ubuntu 18.04) sharing same umask.
- Both Ubuntu 18.04 & 20.04 are initiated using **Cloud Init Extension** with same code. However former allows to run modules for all users, latter after modifying permission to match Ubuntu 18.04 permissions works fine.
- Command used to install module in CloudInit = `Install-Module Az -Scope AllUsers -Confirm:$false -Force`

Trying to install a module to `AllUsers` as `root` on a fresh 20.04 VM gave me permissions of `755` on a newly installed module there (and the module directory itself), so this may be something idiosyncratic to CloudInit.
yah - umask of 027 is removing access for other which is definitely going to be a problem if the user isn't in the appropriate group.
@rjmholt It looks the problem is resolved, so I marked `Resolution-Answered`. Feel free to change the label if there is remaining issues to be looked into.
This issue has been marked as answered and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.
